Cartesian Product
Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.
Polynomial

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
Coefficient of a Polynomial

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.
Ring Isomorphism

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
Factorial ring/unique factorization domain

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.
System of generators
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
Characteristic of a field

Let $K$ be a field (or, more generally, an integral domain) and let $\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K$ be the canonical ring homomorphism. Furthermore, let $p \in \mathbb{N}$ be a generating element of the principal ideal $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then $p$ is called the characteristic of $K$, and we write $p=\operatorname{char} K$.
Integral Element over a Ring

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Stabilizer
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
Dihedral Group

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
